intro: Aciphylla procumbens, commonly known as the cushion chenopod, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the arid regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the family Amaranthaceae and is characterized by its dense, mat-forming growth habit, which helps it conserve moisture in harsh environments. The plant has succulent, fleshy leaves that are often covered in a fine layer of white wax, reducing water loss through transpiration. Its small, inconspicuous flowers are typically green or reddish and appear in clusters during the cooler months. Aciphylla procumbens plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soils and providing habitat for small desert organisms.
